text.content: ClaudeLog
and
GitHub
100% availability

We currently use Claude as our main provider, but will fall back to Google Vertex when Anthropic is down. This is very useful for teams who are building agentic or programmatic workflows. For example, you can't have your AI Code Review bot stop a production release because Anthropic is down.

rich_text.plain_text: We currently use Claude as our main provider, but will fall back to Google Vertex when Anthropic is down. This is very useful for teams who are building agentic or programmatic workflows. For example, you can't have your AI Code Review bot stop a production release because Anthropic is down.

Pricing
Amp usage-based economics
Amp operates on a pay-for-what-you-use pricing model. This is a direct extension of our product philosophy of being "unconstrained in token usage". We apply a margin of 50% on token cost.

rich_text.plain_text: Amp operates on a pay-for-what-you-use pricing model. This is a direct extension of our product philosophy of being "unconstrained in token usage". We apply a margin of 50% on token cost.

text.content: Developers who are highly productive see the direct link between their output and their cost as a fair trade. For teams, this model can simplify billing by linking it directly to the value created. On the other hand, the model introduces a high degree of cost unpredictability. This unpredictability can put off individuals or companies with fixed budgets.

rich_text.plain_text: Developers who are highly productive see the direct link between their output and their cost as a fair trade. For teams, this model can simplify billing by linking it directly to the value created. On the other hand, the model introduces a high degree of cost unpredictability. This unpredictability can put off individuals or companies with fixed budgets.

text.content: Claude Code's tiered subscription and API pricing

rich_text.plain_text: Claude Code's tiered subscription and API pricing

text.content: Claude Code's pricing structure is based on a tiered subscription model with various plans for individuals and teams. Individual developers can access the tool via the Pro ($20/month) or Max ($100/month) plans, while teams can purchase premium seats at $100 per person per month.

rich_text.plain_text: Claude Code's pricing structure is based on a tiered subscription model with various plans for individuals and teams. Individual developers can access the tool via the Pro ($20/month) or Max ($100/month) plans, while teams can purchase premium seats at $100 per person per month.

text.content: However, this subscription-based model is not as predictable as it appears. The plans come with strict usage limits. For example, a Pro user can send approximately 10-40 prompts with Claude Code every five hours, which is sufficient for light work but can be easily exhausted on complex projects. Once these limits are reached, the user must either wait for the limit to reset or switch to a pay-as-you-go model via the Anthropic API console. This effectively creates a hidden, usage-based pricing structure on top of a fixed monthly fee, which can lead to unexpected overage charges for heavy users. This friction point is a key weakness, as it punishes developers for being highly productive and can lead to frustration and a sense of being "throttled" at unpredictable times.

rich_text.plain_text: However, this subscription-based model is not as predictable as it appears. The plans come with strict usage limits. For example, a Pro user can send approximately 10-40 prompts with Claude Code every five hours, which is sufficient for light work but can be easily exhausted on complex projects. Once these limits are reached, the user must either wait for the limit to reset or switch to a pay-as-you-go model via the Anthropic API console. This effectively creates a hidden, usage-based pricing structure on top of a fixed monthly fee, which can lead to unexpected overage charges for heavy users. This friction point is a key weakness, as it punishes developers for being highly productive and can lead to frustration and a sense of being "throttled" at unpredictable times.

text.content: A comparison of the total cost of ownership (TCO) highlights the key difference between the two models. Amp‚Äôs model is transparently usage-based, linking cost to value created, which may appeal to corporate finance departments willing to invest in raw productivity. Claude Code‚Äôs model offers the illusion of a fixed cost, but the reality of its usage caps and API overage charges can be more complex and frustrating for end-users to manage, especially on a large scale.

rich_text.plain_text: A comparison of the total cost of ownership (TCO) highlights the key difference between the two models. Amp‚Äôs model is transparently usage-based, linking cost to value created, which may appeal to corporate finance departments willing to invest in raw productivity. Claude Code‚Äôs model offers the illusion of a fixed cost, but the reality of its usage caps and API overage charges can be more complex and frustrating for end-users to manage, especially on a large scale.

text.content: Pricing model and value analysis
Claude Code's advantages/differences vs Amp
Terminal-native advantage

Claude Code is designed as a command-line tool and ‚Äúmeets you where you already work‚Äù. Unlike GUI-based assistants, it runs entirely in shell and follows Unix philosophy. Claude Code has a certain edge in the terminal over Amp. For instance it has custom commands and hooks (in preview mode in Amp).

rich_text.plain_text: Claude Code is designed as a command-line tool and ‚Äúmeets you where you already work‚Äù. Unlike GUI-based assistants, it runs entirely in shell and follows Unix philosophy. Claude Code has a certain edge in the terminal over Amp. For instance it has custom commands and hooks (in preview mode in Amp).

text.content: Having said that, the new Amp GUI has made significant progress to closing the gap with Claude, but Claude in terminal still has an edge.

rich_text.plain_text: Having said that, the new Amp GUI has made significant progress to closing the gap with Claude, but Claude in terminal still has an edge.

text.content: Mature dev eco system
Claude Code also has a good ecosystem of GitHub projects which enhance the overall dev experience. For instance

rich_text.plain_text: Claude Code also has a good ecosystem of GitHub projects which enhance the overall dev experience. For instance

text.content: awesome-claude-code
or
¬†SuperClaude_Framework
Advanced model and planning capability

Claude Code supports Anthropic‚Äôs top-end Opus model (currently Opus 4.1) for specialized complex reasoning tasks. There is even an opusplan mode that uses Opus during ‚Äúplan mode‚Äù (for architecture and design) and Sonnet 4.5 (its fast code model) for complex agents and coding..

rich_text.plain_text: Claude Code supports Anthropic‚Äôs top-end Opus model (currently Opus 4.1) for specialized complex reasoning tasks. There is even an opusplan mode that uses Opus during ‚Äúplan mode‚Äù (for architecture and design) and Sonnet 4.5 (its fast code model) for complex agents and coding..

text.content: Multi-provider support
Claude Code can
work with
providers like AWS Bedrock, Google Vertex, etc. This means that an org can draw down on GCP or AWS credits against a Google Vertex Claude deployment.

rich_text.plain_text: providers like AWS Bedrock, Google Vertex, etc. This means that an org can draw down on GCP or AWS credits against a Google Vertex Claude deployment.

text.content: In the enterprise many teams are forced to use their internal AWS Bedrock provider for tokens to comply with their internal policies. As a result their Claude Code throughput and tool calling performance will be slow and throttled during peak usage.

rich_text.plain_text: In the enterprise many teams are forced to use their internal AWS Bedrock provider for tokens to comply with their internal policies. As a result their Claude Code throughput and tool calling performance will be slow and throttled during peak usage.

text.content: Amp vs Cursor
Amp advantages over Cursor
Unconstrained token philosophy

Amp's most fundamental advantage is its no token limits approach. While Cursor operates on fixed monthly subscriptions with clear usage limits, Amp provides unlimited token usage within credit balance.

rich_text.plain_text: Amp's most fundamental advantage is its no token limits approach. While Cursor operates on fixed monthly subscriptions with clear usage limits, Amp provides unlimited token usage within credit balance.

text.content: This means developers never hit artificial walls during critical development sessions, unlike Cursor users who may face monthly caps that restrict productivity during intensive coding periods.

rich_text.plain_text: This means developers never hit artificial walls during critical development sessions, unlike Cursor users who may face monthly caps that restrict productivity during intensive coding periods.

text.content: 100% availability

We currently use Claude as our main provider, but will fall back to Google Vertex when Anthropic is down. Cursor's reliance on multiple model providers offers flexibility but doesn't guarantee the same fallback reliability during outages.

text.content: Cursor's pricing structure is based on a tiered subscription model with various plans for individuals and teams. Individual developers can access the tool via multiple tiers:

text.content: Hobby Plan (Free)
: 2,000 completions and 50 slow premium requests per month, plus a 2-week Pro trial

rich_text.plain_text: : 2,000 completions and 50 slow premium requests per month, plus a 2-week Pro trial

text.content: Pro Plan
: $20/month ($16/month annually) with 500 fast premium requests per month and unlimited slow requests

rich_text.plain_text: : $20/month ($16/month annually) with 500 fast premium requests per month and unlimited slow requests

text.content: Business Plan
: $40/month per user ($32/month annually) with team collaboration features and admin controls

rich_text.plain_text: : $40/month per user ($32/month annually) with team collaboration features and admin controls

text.content: Ultra Plan
: $200/month providing 20x more usage than Pro tier for high-volume enterprise users

rich_text.plain_text: : $200/month providing 20x more usage than Pro tier for high-volume enterprise users

text.content: However, this subscription-based model is not as predictable as it appears. The plans come with strict usage limits, and Cursor operates different modes that consume requests at varying rates:

rich_text.plain_text: However, this subscription-based model is not as predictable as it appears. The plans come with strict usage limits, and Cursor operates different modes that consume requests at varying rates:

text.content: Normal Mode
: Fixed request consumption per message (predictable)
Max Mode
: Token-based pricing at API cost + 20% margin (can rapidly consume multiple requests per interaction)

rich_text.plain_text: : Token-based pricing at API cost + 20% margin (can rapidly consume multiple requests per interaction)

text.content: Once usage limits are reached, users must either wait for limits to reset or pay additional usage-based charges. For example, a complex Max Mode interaction with 135k input tokens might cost 2.7 requests, while the model's 82k token response could cost another 1.23 requests, totaling nearly 4 requests for a single exchange.

rich_text.plain_text: Once usage limits are reached, users must either wait for limits to reset or pay additional usage-based charges. For example, a complex Max Mode interaction with 135k input tokens might cost 2.7 requests, while the model's 82k token response could cost another 1.23 requests, totaling nearly 4 requests for a single exchange.

text.content: This effectively creates a hidden, usage-based pricing structure on top of fixed monthly fees, which can lead to unexpected overage charges for heavy users. This friction point punishes developers for being highly productive and can lead to frustration at unpredictable times.

text.content: Pricing model and value analysis
Cursor's advantages/differences vs Amp
Integrated editor experience

Cursor provides a native VSCode fork with a familiar interface. Developers can use their existing VSCode knowledge and muscle memory without learning new tools or workflows. This integrated approach eliminates context switching.

rich_text.plain_text: Cursor provides a native VSCode fork with a familiar interface. Developers can use their existing VSCode knowledge and muscle memory without learning new tools or workflows. This integrated approach eliminates context switching.

text.content: Predictable pricing model
Cursor operates on fixed monthly subscriptions with clear usage limits. This provides cost predictability that appeals to individuals and organizations with fixed budgets.

rich_text.plain_text: Cursor operates on fixed monthly subscriptions with clear usage limits. This provides cost predictability that appeals to individuals and organizations with fixed budgets.

Unconstrained token philosophy

rich_text.plain_text: While Windsurf has SWE-1-mini for passive suggestions optimized for real-time latency, it lacks Amp's multi-source context integration and semantic awareness.

text.content: Enterprise-grade features
Amp delivers enterprise collaboration capabilities:
Workspace collaboration with shared thread libraries

rich_text.plain_text: Workspace collaboration with shared thread libraries

text.content: Git co-authoring with automatic thread linking in commits

rich_text.plain_text: Git co-authoring with automatic thread linking in commits

text.content: Leaderboards tracking team contributions
Windsurf focuses on individual developer experience within their AI-native IDE without these enterprise collaboration features.

rich_text.plain_text: Windsurf focuses on individual developer experience within their AI-native IDE without these enterprise collaboration features.

text.content: Pricing
Amp usage-based economics
Amp operates on a pay-for-what-you-use pricing model. This is a direct extension of its product philosophy of being "unconstrained in token usage". We apply a margin of 50% on token cost.

rich_text.plain_text: Amp operates on a pay-for-what-you-use pricing model. This is a direct extension of its product philosophy of being "unconstrained in token usage". We apply a margin of 50% on token cost.

text.content: Developers who are highly productive see the direct link between their output and their cost as a fair trade. For teams, this model can simplify billing by linking it directly to the value created. On the other hand, the model introduces a high degree of cost unpredictability. This unpredictability can put off individuals or companies with fixed budgets.

rich_text.plain_text: Developers who are highly productive see the direct link between their output and their cost as a fair trade. For teams, this model can simplify billing by linking it directly to the value created. On the other hand, the model introduces a high degree of cost unpredictability. This unpredictability can put off individuals or companies with fixed budgets.

text.content: Windsurf's simplified credit-based pricing
Windsurf operates on a credit-based pricing model that was recently simplified. After moving away from complex "flow action credits," Windsurf now uses a straightforward 1:1 prompt credit system:

rich_text.plain_text: Windsurf operates on a credit-based pricing model that was recently simplified. After moving away from complex "flow action credits," Windsurf now uses a straightforward 1:1 prompt credit system:

text.content: Free Plan
: Unlimited IDE usage with SWE-1 Lite model, 50 user prompt credits, and 200 flow action credits per month

rich_text.plain_text: : Unlimited IDE usage with SWE-1 Lite model, 50 user prompt credits, and 200 flow action credits per month

text.content: Pro Plan
: $15/month for 500 prompt credits (equivalent to approximately 2,000 GPT-4.1 prompts, since complex models consume 4 prompts per credit)

rich_text.plain_text: : $15/month for 500 prompt credits (equivalent to approximately 2,000 GPT-4.1 prompts, since complex models consume 4 prompts per credit)

text.content: Teams Plan
: $60/month for collaborative features and enhanced security

rich_text.plain_text: : $60/month for collaborative features and enhanced security

text.content: Enterprise Plan
: Custom pricing with advanced security, compliance, and scaling features

rich_text.plain_text: : Custom pricing with advanced security, compliance, and scaling features

text.content: Windsurf's credit system is more predictable than traditional usage-based models, as users know exactly how many interactions they can have each month. However, different AI models consume credits at different rates - more powerful models like SWE-1 consume more credits per interaction than lighter models like SWE-1 Lite.

rich_text.plain_text: Windsurf's credit system is more predictable than traditional usage-based models, as users know exactly how many interactions they can have each month. However, different AI models consume credits at different rates - more powerful models like SWE-1 consume more credits per interaction than lighter models like SWE-1 Lite.

text.content: The main limitation is that once credits are exhausted, users cannot continue using advanced AI features until the next billing cycle or until they purchase additional credit packs (starting at $15 for 100 credits). This creates periodic productivity barriers similar to Cursor's request limits, though Windsurf's unlimited IDE usage with their basic model provides some continuity.

rich_text.plain_text: The main limitation is that once credits are exhausted, users cannot continue using advanced AI features until the next billing cycle or until they purchase additional credit packs (starting at $15 for 100 credits). This creates periodic productivity barriers similar to Cursor's request limits, though Windsurf's unlimited IDE usage with their basic model provides some continuity.

text.content: Pricing model and value analysis
Windsurf's advantages/differences vs Amp
AI-native IDE philosophy

Windsurf is built from the ground up as an "AI-native IDE" rather than adding AI capabilities to existing tools. This fundamental approach means every aspect of the development environment is designed with AI integration in mind.

rich_text.plain_text: Windsurf is built from the ground up as an "AI-native IDE" rather than adding AI capabilities to existing tools. This fundamental approach means every aspect of the development environment is designed with AI integration in mind.

text.content: This creates a more cohesive experience compared to Amp's multi-platform approach which requires adapting to different host environments.

rich_text.plain_text: This creates a more cohesive experience compared to Amp's multi-platform approach which requires adapting to different host environments.

text.content: Deep codebase understanding with Cascade

Windsurf's Cascade system combines deep codebase understanding, advanced tools, and real-time awareness of developer actions. The AI-driven context system automatically indexes entire codebases through retrieval-augmented generation (RAG).

rich_text.plain_text: Windsurf's Cascade system combines deep codebase understanding, advanced tools, and real-time awareness of developer actions. The AI-driven context system automatically indexes entire codebases through retrieval-augmented generation (RAG).

text.content: This provides comprehensive project awareness that goes beyond Amp's thread-based context management.

rich_text.plain_text: This provides comprehensive project awareness that goes beyond Amp's thread-based context management.

Advanced memory and context system
Cascade includes a memories feature where the agent saves details about users across different chats within the same project, providing better context for answers over time.

rich_text.plain_text: Cascade includes a memories feature where the agent saves details about users across different chats within the same project, providing better context for answers over time.

text.content: This persistent memory system creates continuity across sessions that differs from Amp's thread-based approach.

rich_text.plain_text: This persistent memory system creates continuity across sessions that differs from Amp's thread-based approach.
